OptionParser.description:
--
== Developer Documentation (not for RDoc output)

=== Class tree

- OptionParser:: front end
- OptionParser::Switch:: each switches
- OptionParser::List:: options list
- OptionParser::ParseError:: errors on parsing
  - OptionParser::AmbiguousOption
  - OptionParser::NeedlessArgument
  - OptionParser::MissingArgument
  - OptionParser::InvalidOption
  - OptionParser::InvalidArgument
    - OptionParser::AmbiguousArgument

=== Object relationship diagram

  +--------------+
  | OptionParser |<>-----+
  +--------------+       |                      +--------+
                         |                    ,-| Switch |
       on_head -------->+---------------+    /  +--------+
       accept/reject -->| List          |<|>-
                        |               |<|>-  +----------+
       on ------------->+---------------+    `-| argument |
                          :           :        |  class   |
                        +---------------+      |==========|
       on_tail -------->|               |      |pattern   |
                        +---------------+      |----------|
  OptionParser.accept ->| DefaultList   |      |converter |
               reject   |(shared between|      +----------+
                        | all instances)|
                        +---------------+

++

== OptionParser

=== Introduction

OptionParser is a class for command-line option analysis.  It is much more
advanced, yet also easier to use, than GetoptLong, and is a more Ruby-oriented
solution.

=== Features

1. The argument specification and the code to handle it are written in the
   same place.
2. It can output an option summary; you don't need to maintain this string
   separately.
3. Optional and mandatory arguments are specified very gracefully.
4. Arguments can be automatically converted to a specified class.
5. Arguments can be restricted to a certain set.

All of these features are demonstrated in the examples below.  See
#make_switch for full documentation.

=== Minimal example

  require 'optparse'

  options = {}
  OptionParser.new do |opts|
    opts.banner = "Usage: example.rb [options]"

    opts.on("-v", "--[no-]verbose", "Run verbosely") do |v|
      options[:verbose] = v
    end
  end.parse!

  p options
  p ARGV

=== Generating Help

OptionParser can be used to automatically generate help for the commands you
write:

  require 'optparse'

  Options = Struct.new(:name)

  class Parser
    def self.parse(options)
      args = Options.new("world")

      opt_parser = OptionParser.new do |opts|
        opts.banner = "Usage: example.rb [options]"

        opts.on("-nNAME", "--name=NAME", "Name to say hello to") do |n|
          args.name = n
        end

        opts.on("-h", "--help", "Prints this help") do
          puts opts
          exit
        end
      end

      opt_parser.parse!(options)
      return args
    end
  end
  options = Parser.parse %w[--help]

  #=>
     # Usage: example.rb [options]
     #     -n, --name=NAME                  Name to say hello to
     #     -h, --help                       Prints this help#

=== Complete example

The following example is a complete Ruby program.  You can run it and see the
effect of specifying various options.  This is probably the best way to learn
the features of +optparse+.

  require 'optparse'
  require 'optparse/time'
  require 'ostruct'
  require 'pp'

  class OptparseExample

    CODES = %w[iso-2022-jp shift_jis euc-jp utf8 binary]
    CODE_ALIASES = { "jis" => "iso-2022-jp", "sjis" => "shift_jis" }

    #
    # Return a structure describing the options.
    #
    def self.parse(args)
      # The options specified on the command line will be collected in *options*.
      # We set default values here.
      options = OpenStruct.new
      options.library = []
      options.inplace = false
      options.encoding = "utf8"
      options.transfer_type = :auto
      options.verbose = false

      opt_parser = OptionParser.new do |opts|
        opts.banner = "Usage: example.rb [options]"

        opts.separator ""
        opts.separator "Specific options:"

        # Mandatory argument.
        opts.on("-r", "--require LIBRARY",
                "Require the LIBRARY before executing your script") do |lib|
          options.library << lib
        end

        # Optional argument; multi-line description.
        opts.on("-i", "--inplace [EXTENSION]",
                "Edit ARGV files in place",
                "  (make backup if EXTENSION supplied)") do |ext|
          options.inplace = true
          options.extension = ext || ''
          options.extension.sub!(/\A\.?(?=.)/, ".")  # Ensure extension begins with dot.
        end

        # Cast 'delay' argument to a Float.
        opts.on("--delay N", Float, "Delay N seconds before executing") do |n|
          options.delay = n
        end

        # Cast 'time' argument to a Time object.
        opts.on("-t", "--time [TIME]", Time, "Begin execution at given time") do |time|
          options.time = time
        end

        # Cast to octal integer.
        opts.on("-F", "--irs [OCTAL]", OptionParser::OctalInteger,
                "Specify record separator (default \\0)") do |rs|
          options.record_separator = rs
        end

        # List of arguments.
        opts.on("--list x,y,z", Array, "Example 'list' of arguments") do |list|
          options.list = list
        end

        # Keyword completion.  We are specifying a specific set of arguments (CODES
        # and CODE_ALIASES - notice the latter is a Hash), and the user may provide
        # the shortest unambiguous text.
        code_list = (CODE_ALIASES.keys + CODES).join(',')
        opts.on("--code CODE", CODES, CODE_ALIASES, "Select encoding",
                "  (#{code_list})") do |encoding|
          options.encoding = encoding
        end

        # Optional argument with keyword completion.
        opts.on("--type [TYPE]", [:text, :binary, :auto],
                "Select transfer type (text, binary, auto)") do |t|
          options.transfer_type = t
        end

        # Boolean switch.
        opts.on("-v", "--[no-]verbose", "Run verbosely") do |v|
          options.verbose = v
        end

        opts.separator ""
        opts.separator "Common options:"

        # No argument, shows at tail.  This will print an options summary.
        # Try it and see!
        opts.on_tail("-h", "--help", "Show this message") do
          puts opts
          exit
        end

        # Another typical switch to print the version.
        opts.on_tail("--version", "Show version") do
          puts ::Version.join('.')
          exit
        end
      end

      opt_parser.parse!(args)
      options
    end  # parse()

  end  # class OptparseExample

  options = OptparseExample.parse(ARGV)
  pp options
  pp ARGV

=== Shell Completion

For modern shells (e.g. bash, zsh, etc.), you can use shell
completion for command line options.

=== Further documentation

The above examples should be enough to learn how to use this class.  If you
have any questions, file a ticket at http://bugs.ruby-lang.org.
OptionParser.name: OptionParser

OptionParser#accept.description:
Directs to accept specified class +t+. The argument string is passed to
the block in which it should be converted to the desired class.

+t+::   Argument class specifier, any object including Class.
+pat+:: Pattern for argument, defaults to +t+ if it responds to match.

  accept(t, pat, &block)
OptionParser#accept.name: accept

OptionParser#set_banner.description:
Heading banner preceding summary.
for experimental cascading :-)
OptionParser#set_banner.name: set_banner

OptionParser#complete.description:
Completes shortened long style option switch and returns pair of
canonical switch and switch descriptor OptionParser::Switch.

+id+::    Searching table.
+opt+::   Searching key.
+icase+:: Search case insensitive if true.
+pat+::   Optional pattern for completion.
OptionParser#complete.name: complete

OptionParser#default_argv.description: Strings to be parsed in default.
OptionParser#default_argv.name: default_argv

OptionParser#default_argv=.description: Strings to be parsed in default.
OptionParser#default_argv=.name: default_argv=

OptionParser#environment.description:
Parses environment variable +env+ or its uppercase with splitting like a
shell.

+env+ defaults to the basename of the program.
OptionParser#environment.name: environment

OptionParser#getopts.description:
Wrapper method for getopts.rb.

  params = ARGV.getopts("ab:", "foo", "bar:", "zot:Z;zot option)
  # params[:a] = true   # -a
  # params[:b] = "1"    # -b1
  # params[:foo] = "1"  # --foo
  # params[:bar] = "x"  # --bar x
  # params[:zot] = "z"  # --zot Z
OptionParser#getopts.name: getopts

OptionParser#initialize.description:
Initializes the instance and yields itself if called with a block.

+banner+:: Banner message.
+width+::  Summary width.
+indent+:: Summary indent.
OptionParser#initialize.name: initialize

OptionParser#load.description:
Loads options from file names as +filename+. Does nothing when the file
is not present. Returns whether successfully loaded.

+filename+ defaults to basename of the program without suffix in a
directory ~/.options.
OptionParser#load.name: load

OptionParser#make_switch.description:
Creates an OptionParser::Switch from the parameters. The parsed argument
value is passed to the given block, where it can be processed.

See at the beginning of OptionParser for some full examples.

+opts+ can include the following elements:

[Argument style:]
  One of the following:
    :NONE, :REQUIRED, :OPTIONAL

[Argument pattern:]
  Acceptable option argument format, must be pre-defined with
  OptionParser.accept or OptionParser#accept, or Regexp. This can appear
  once or assigned as String if not present, otherwise causes an
  ArgumentError. Examples:
    Float, Time, Array

[Possible argument values:]
  Hash or Array.
    [:text, :binary, :auto]
    %w[iso-2022-jp shift_jis euc-jp utf8 binary]
    { "jis" => "iso-2022-jp", "sjis" => "shift_jis" }

[Long style switch:]
  Specifies a long style switch which takes a mandatory, optional or no
  argument. It's a string of the following form:
    "--switch=MANDATORY" or "--switch MANDATORY"
    "--switch[=OPTIONAL]"
    "--switch"

[Short style switch:]
  Specifies short style switch which takes a mandatory, optional or no
  argument. It's a string of the following form:
    "-xMANDATORY"
    "-x[OPTIONAL]"
    "-x"
  There is also a special form which matches character range (not full
  set of regular expression):
    "-[a-z]MANDATORY"
    "-[a-z][OPTIONAL]"
    "-[a-z]"

[Argument style and description:]
  Instead of specifying mandatory or optional arguments directly in the
  switch parameter, this separate parameter can be used.
    "=MANDATORY"
    "=[OPTIONAL]"

[Description:]
  Description string for the option.
    "Run verbosely"

[Handler:]
  Handler for the parsed argument value. Either give a block or pass a
  Proc or Method as an argument.
OptionParser#make_switch.name: make_switch

OptionParser#notwice.description:
Checks if an argument is given twice, in which case an ArgumentError is
raised. Called from OptionParser#switch only.

+obj+:: New argument.
+prv+:: Previously specified argument.
+msg+:: Exception message.
OptionParser#notwice.name: notwice

OptionParser#on.description:
Add option switch and handler. See #make_switch for an explanation of
parameters.
OptionParser#on.name: on

OptionParser#on_head.description: Add option switch like with #on, but at head of summary.
OptionParser#on_head.name: on_head

OptionParser#on_tail.description: Add option switch like with #on, but at tail of summary.
OptionParser#on_tail.name: on_tail

OptionParser#order.description:
Parses command line arguments +argv+ in order. When a block is given,
each non-option argument is yielded.

Returns the rest of +argv+ left unparsed.
OptionParser#order.name: order

OptionParser#order!.description:
Same as #order, but removes switches destructively.
Non-option arguments remain in +argv+.
OptionParser#order!.name: order!

OptionParser#parse.description:
Parses command line arguments +argv+ in order when environment variable
POSIXLY_CORRECT is set, and in permutation mode otherwise.
OptionParser#parse.name: parse

OptionParser#parse!.description:
Same as #parse, but removes switches destructively.
Non-option arguments remain in +argv+.
OptionParser#parse!.name: parse!

OptionParser#permute.description:
Parses command line arguments +argv+ in permutation mode and returns
list of non-option arguments.
OptionParser#permute.name: permute

OptionParser#permute!.description:
Same as #permute, but removes switches destructively.
Non-option arguments remain in +argv+.
OptionParser#permute!.name: permute!

OptionParser#program_name.description:
Program name to be emitted in error message and default banner, defaults
to $0.
OptionParser#program_name.name: program_name

OptionParser#program_name=.description:
Program name to be emitted in error message and default banner,
defaults to $0.
OptionParser#program_name=.name: set_program_name

OptionParser#set_program_name.description:
Program name to be emitted in error message and default banner,
defaults to $0.
OptionParser#set_program_name.name: set_program_name

OptionParser#reject.description:
Directs to reject specified class argument.

+t+:: Argument class specifier, any object including Class.

  reject(t)
OptionParser#reject.name: reject

OptionParser#search.description: Searches +key+ in @stack for +id+ hash and returns or yields the result.
OptionParser#search.name: search

OptionParser#set_summary_indent.description: Indentation for summary. Must be String (or have + String method).
OptionParser#set_summary_indent.name: set_summary_indent

OptionParser#set_summary_width.description: Width for option list portion of summary. Must be Numeric.
OptionParser#set_summary_width.name: set_summary_width

OptionParser#summarize.description:
Puts option summary into +to+ and returns +to+. Yields each line if
a block is given.

+to+:: Output destination, which must have method <<. Defaults to [].
+width+:: Width of left side, defaults to @summary_width.
+max+:: Maximum length allowed for left side, defaults to +width+ - 1.
+indent+:: Indentation, defaults to @summary_indent.
OptionParser#summarize.name: summarize

OptionParser#summary_indent.description: Indentation for summary. Must be String (or have + String method).
OptionParser#summary_indent.name: summary_indent

OptionParser#summary_indent=.description: Indentation for summary. Must be String (or have + String method).
OptionParser#summary_indent=.name: set_summary_indent

OptionParser#summary_width.description: Width for option list portion of summary. Must be Numeric.
OptionParser#summary_width.name: summary_width

OptionParser#summary_width=.description: Width for option list portion of summary. Must be Numeric.
OptionParser#summary_width=.name: set_summary_width

OptionParser#terminate.description:
Terminates option parsing. Optional parameter +arg+ is a string pushed
back to be the first non-option argument.
OptionParser#terminate.name: terminate

OptionParser#ver.description: Returns version string from program_name, version and release.
OptionParser#ver.name: ver

OptionParser#visit.description:
Traverses @stack, sending each element method +id+ with +args+ and
+block+.
OptionParser#visit.name: visit

OptionParser.inc.description: Returns an incremented value of +default+ according to +arg+.
OptionParser.inc.name: inc

OptionParser.with.description:
Initializes a new instance and evaluates the optional block in context
of the instance. Arguments +args+ are passed to #new, see there for
description of parameters.

This method is *deprecated*, its behavior corresponds to the older #new
method.
OptionParser.with.name: with

OptionParser::Acceptables.description:
Acceptable argument classes. Now contains DecimalInteger, OctalInteger
and DecimalNumeric. See Acceptable argument classes (in source code).
OptionParser::Acceptables.name: Acceptables

OptionParser::AmbiguousArgument.description: Raises when the given argument word can't be completed uniquely.
OptionParser::AmbiguousArgument.name: AmbiguousArgument

OptionParser::AmbiguousOption.description: Raises when ambiguously completable string is encountered.
OptionParser::AmbiguousOption.name: AmbiguousOption

OptionParser::Arguable.description: Extends command line arguments array (ARGV) to parse itself.
OptionParser::Arguable.name: Arguable

OptionParser::Arguable#getopts.description:
Substitution of getopts is possible as follows. Also see
OptionParser#getopts.

  def getopts(*args)
    ($OPT = ARGV.getopts(*args)).each do |opt, val|
      eval "$OPT_#{opt.gsub(/[^A-Za-z0-9_]/, '_')} = val"
    end
  rescue OptionParser::ParseError
  end
OptionParser::Arguable#getopts.name: getopts

OptionParser::Arguable#options.description:
Actual OptionParser object, automatically created if nonexistent.

If called with a block, yields the OptionParser object and returns the
result of the block. If an OptionParser::ParseError exception occurs
in the block, it is rescued, a error message printed to STDERR and
+nil+ returned.
OptionParser::Arguable#options.name: options

OptionParser::Arguable#options=.description:
Sets OptionParser object, when +opt+ is +false+ or +nil+, methods
OptionParser::Arguable#options and OptionParser::Arguable#options= are
undefined. Thus, there is no ways to access the OptionParser object
via the receiver object.
OptionParser::Arguable#options=.name: options=

OptionParser::Arguable#order!.description:
Parses +self+ destructively in order and returns +self+ containing the
rest arguments left unparsed.
OptionParser::Arguable#order!.name: order!

OptionParser::Arguable#parse!.description:
Parses +self+ destructively and returns +self+ containing the
rest arguments left unparsed.
OptionParser::Arguable#parse!.name: parse!

OptionParser::Arguable#permute!.description:
Parses +self+ destructively in permutation mode and returns +self+
containing the rest arguments left unparsed.
OptionParser::Arguable#permute!.name: permute!

OptionParser::ArgumentStyle.description:
Enumeration of acceptable argument styles. Possible values are:

NO_ARGUMENT::       The switch takes no arguments. (:NONE)
REQUIRED_ARGUMENT:: The switch requires an argument. (:REQUIRED)
OPTIONAL_ARGUMENT:: The switch requires an optional argument. (:OPTIONAL)

Use like --switch=argument (long style) or -Xargument (short style). For
short style, only portion matched to argument pattern is treated as
argument.
OptionParser::ArgumentStyle.name: ArgumentStyle

OptionParser::CompletingHash.description: Hash with completion search feature. See OptionParser::Completion.
OptionParser::CompletingHash.name: CompletingHash

OptionParser::Completion.description:
Keyword completion module.  This allows partial arguments to be specified
and resolved against a list of acceptable values.
OptionParser::Completion.name: Completion

OptionParser::DecimalInteger.description: Decimal integer format, to be converted to Integer.
OptionParser::DecimalInteger.name: DecimalInteger

OptionParser::DecimalNumeric.description:
Decimal integer/float number format, to be converted to Integer for
integer format, Float for float format.
OptionParser::DecimalNumeric.name: DecimalNumeric

OptionParser::DefaultList.description:
Switches common used such as '--', and also provides default
argument classes
OptionParser::DefaultList.name: DefaultList

OptionParser::InvalidArgument.description: Raises when the given argument does not match required format.
OptionParser::InvalidArgument.name: InvalidArgument

OptionParser::List.description:
Simple option list providing mapping from short and/or long option
string to OptionParser::Switch and mapping from acceptable argument to
matching pattern and converter pair. Also provides summary feature.
OptionParser::List.name: List

OptionParser::List#append.description:
Appends +switch+ at the tail of the list, and associates short, long
and negated long options. Arguments are:

+switch+::      OptionParser::Switch instance to be inserted.
+short_opts+::  List of short style options.
+long_opts+::   List of long style options.
+nolong_opts+:: List of long style options with "no-" prefix.

  append(switch, short_opts, long_opts, nolong_opts)
OptionParser::List#append.name: append

OptionParser::List#atype.description: Map from acceptable argument types to pattern and converter pairs.
OptionParser::List#atype.name: atype

OptionParser::List#complete.description:
Searches list +id+ for +opt+ and the optional patterns for completion
+pat+. If +icase+ is true, the search is case insensitive. The result
is returned or yielded if a block is given. If it isn't found, nil is
returned.
OptionParser::List#complete.name: complete

OptionParser::List#each_option.description: Iterates over each option, passing the option to the +block+.
OptionParser::List#each_option.name: each_option

OptionParser::List#list.description: List of all switches and summary string.
OptionParser::List#list.name: list

OptionParser::List#long.description: Map from long style option switches to actual switch objects.
OptionParser::List#long.name: long

OptionParser::List#prepend.description:
Inserts +switch+ at the head of the list, and associates short, long
and negated long options. Arguments are:

+switch+::      OptionParser::Switch instance to be inserted.
+short_opts+::  List of short style options.
+long_opts+::   List of long style options.
+nolong_opts+:: List of long style options with "no-" prefix.

  prepend(switch, short_opts, long_opts, nolong_opts)
OptionParser::List#prepend.name: prepend

OptionParser::List#search.description:
Searches +key+ in +id+ list. The result is returned or yielded if a
block is given. If it isn't found, nil is returned.
OptionParser::List#search.name: search

OptionParser::List#short.description: Map from short style option switches to actual switch objects.
OptionParser::List#short.name: short

OptionParser::List#summarize.description:
Creates the summary table, passing each line to the +block+ (without
newline). The arguments +args+ are passed along to the summarize
method which is called on every option.
OptionParser::List#summarize.name: summarize

OptionParser::List#update.description:
Adds +sw+ according to +sopts+, +lopts+ and +nlopts+.

+sw+::     OptionParser::Switch instance to be added.
+sopts+::  Short style option list.
+lopts+::  Long style option list.
+nlopts+:: Negated long style options list.
OptionParser::List#update.name: update

OptionParser::MissingArgument.description: Raises when a switch with mandatory argument has no argument.
OptionParser::MissingArgument.name: MissingArgument

OptionParser::NeedlessArgument.description: Raises when there is an argument for a switch which takes no argument.
OptionParser::NeedlessArgument.name: NeedlessArgument

OptionParser::OctalInteger.description:
Ruby/C like octal/hexadecimal/binary integer format, to be converted to
Integer.
OptionParser::OctalInteger.name: OctalInteger

OptionParser::Officious.description: Default options for ARGV, which never appear in option summary.
OptionParser::Officious.name: Officious

OptionParser::OptionMap.description: Map from option/keyword string to object with completion.
OptionParser::OptionMap.name: OptionMap

OptionParser::ParseError.description: Base class of exceptions from OptionParser.
OptionParser::ParseError.name: ParseError

OptionParser::ParseError#args.description: Returns the value of attribute args
OptionParser::ParseError#args.name: args

OptionParser::ParseError#message.description: Default stringizing method to emit standard error message.
OptionParser::ParseError#message.name: to_s

OptionParser::ParseError#to_s.description: Default stringizing method to emit standard error message.
OptionParser::ParseError#to_s.name: to_s

OptionParser::ParseError#reason.description: Returns error reason. Override this for I18N.
OptionParser::ParseError#reason.name: reason

OptionParser::ParseError#reason=.name: reason=
parameters: the value to set the attribute reason to.

OptionParser::Switch.description:
Individual switch class.  Not important to the user.

Defined within Switch are several Switch-derived classes: NoArgument,
RequiredArgument, etc.
OptionParser::Switch.name: Switch

OptionParser::Switch#arg.description: Returns the value of attribute arg
OptionParser::Switch#arg.name: arg

OptionParser::Switch#block.description: Returns the value of attribute block
OptionParser::Switch#block.name: block

OptionParser::Switch#conv.description: Returns the value of attribute conv
OptionParser::Switch#conv.name: conv

OptionParser::Switch#conv_arg.description:
Parses argument, converts and returns +arg+, +block+ and result of
conversion. Yields at semi-error condition instead of raising an
exception.
OptionParser::Switch#conv_arg.name: conv_arg

OptionParser::Switch#desc.description: Returns the value of attribute desc
OptionParser::Switch#desc.name: desc

OptionParser::Switch#long.description: Returns the value of attribute long
OptionParser::Switch#long.name: long

OptionParser::Switch#parse_arg.description:
Parses +arg+ and returns rest of +arg+ and matched portion to the
argument pattern. Yields when the pattern doesn't match substring.
OptionParser::Switch#parse_arg.name: parse_arg

OptionParser::Switch#pattern.description: Returns the value of attribute pattern
OptionParser::Switch#pattern.name: pattern

OptionParser::Switch#short.description: Returns the value of attribute short
OptionParser::Switch#short.name: short

OptionParser::Switch#summarize.description:
Produces the summary text. Each line of the summary is yielded to the
block (without newline).

+sdone+::  Already summarized short style options keyed hash.
+ldone+::  Already summarized long style options keyed hash.
+width+::  Width of left side (option part). In other words, the right
           side (description part) starts after +width+ columns.
+max+::    Maximum width of left side -> the options are filled within
           +max+ columns.
+indent+:: Prefix string indents all summarized lines.
OptionParser::Switch#summarize.name: summarize

OptionParser::Switch.guess.description:
Guesses argument style from +arg+.  Returns corresponding
OptionParser::Switch class (OptionalArgument, etc.).
OptionParser::Switch.guess.name: guess

OptionParser::Switch::NoArgument#parse.description: Raises an exception if any arguments given.
OptionParser::Switch::NoArgument#parse.name: parse

OptionParser::Switch::OptionalArgument#p.description: Parses argument if given, or uses default value.
OptionParser::Switch::OptionalArgument#p.name: parse

OptionParser::Switch::PlacedArgument.description: Switch that takes an argument, which does not begin with '-'.
OptionParser::Switch::PlacedArgument.name: PlacedArgument

OptionParser::Switch::PlacedArgument#par.description: Returns nil if argument is not present or begins with '-'.
OptionParser::Switch::PlacedArgument#par.name: parse

OptionParser::Switch::RequiredArgument#p.description: Raises an exception if argument is not present.
OptionParser::Switch::RequiredArgument#p.name: parse

OpenStruct#==.description:
Compares this object and +other+ for equality.  An OpenStruct is equal to
+other+ when +other+ is an OpenStruct and the two objects' Hash tables are
equal.

OpenStruct#[].description:
Returns the value of a member.

  person = OpenStruct.new('name' => 'John Smith', 'age' => 70)
  person[:age] # => 70, same as ostruct.age

OpenStruct#[]=.description:
Sets the value of a member.

  person = OpenStruct.new('name' => 'John Smith', 'age' => 70)
  person[:age] = 42 # => equivalent to ostruct.age = 42
  person.age # => 42

OpenStruct#as_json.description:
Returns a hash, that will be turned into a JSON object and represent this
object.
OpenStruct#as_json.name: as_json

OpenStruct#delete_field.description:
Remove the named field from the object. Returns the value that the field
contained if it was defined.

  require 'ostruct'

  person = OpenStruct.new('name' => 'John Smith', 'age' => 70)

  person.delete_field('name')  # => 'John Smith'
OpenStruct#delete_field.name: delete_field

OpenStruct#each_pair.description:
Yields all attributes (as a symbol) along with the corresponding values
or returns an enumerator if not block is given.
Example:

  require 'ostruct'
  data = OpenStruct.new("country" => "Australia", :population => 20_000_000)
  data.each_pair.to_a  # => [[:country, "Australia"], [:population, 20000000]]
OpenStruct#each_pair.name: each_pair

OpenStruct#eql?.description:
Compares this object and +other+ for equality.  An OpenStruct is eql? to
+other+ when +other+ is an OpenStruct and the two objects' Hash tables are
eql?.
OpenStruct#eql?.name: eql?

OpenStruct#hash.description:
Compute a hash-code for this OpenStruct.
Two hashes with the same content will have the same hash code
(and will be eql?).
OpenStruct#hash.name: hash

OpenStruct#initialize.description:
Creates a new OpenStruct object.  By default, the resulting OpenStruct
object will have no attributes.

The optional +hash+, if given, will generate attributes and values
(can be a Hash, an OpenStruct or a Struct).
For example:

  require 'ostruct'
  hash = { "country" => "Australia", :population => 20_000_000 }
  data = OpenStruct.new(hash)

  p data        # -> <OpenStruct country="Australia" population=20000000>
OpenStruct#initialize.name: initialize

OpenStruct#inspect.description: Returns a string containing a detailed summary of the keys and values.
OpenStruct#inspect.name: to_s

OpenStruct#to_s.description: Returns a string containing a detailed summary of the keys and values.
OpenStruct#to_s.name: to_s

OpenStruct#marshal_dump.description: Provides marshalling support for use by the Marshal library.
OpenStruct#marshal_dump.name: marshal_dump

OpenStruct#marshal_load.description: Provides marshalling support for use by the Marshal library.
OpenStruct#marshal_load.name: marshal_load

OpenStruct#modifiable.description:
Used internally to check if the OpenStruct is able to be
modified before granting access to the internal Hash table to be modified.
OpenStruct#modifiable.name: modifiable

OpenStruct#new_ostruct_member.description:
Used internally to defined properties on the
OpenStruct. It does this by using the metaprogramming function
define_singleton_method for both the getter method and the setter method.
OpenStruct#new_ostruct_member.name: new_ostruct_member

OpenStruct#to_h.description:
Converts the OpenStruct to a hash with keys representing
each attribute (as symbols) and their corresponding values
Example:

  require 'ostruct'
  data = OpenStruct.new("country" => "Australia", :population => 20_000_000)
  data.to_h   # => {:country => "Australia", :population => 20000000 }
OpenStruct#to_h.name: to_h

OpenStruct#to_json.description:
Stores class name (OpenStruct) with this struct's values <tt>v</tt> as a
JSON string.
OpenStruct#to_json.name: to_json

OpenStruct.json_create.description:
Deserializes JSON string by constructing new Struct object with values
<tt>v</tt> serialized by <tt>to_json</tt>.
OpenStruct.json_create.name: json_create

PP.description: A pretty-printer for Ruby objects. All examples assume you have loaded the PP class with: require 'pp' == What PP Does Standard output by #p returns this: #, @group_queue=#], []]>, @buffer=[], @newline="\n", @group_stack=[#], @buffer_width=0, @indent=0, @maxwidth=79, @output_width=2, @output=#> Pretty-printed output returns this: #, @group_queue= #], []]>, @group_stack= [#], @indent=0, @maxwidth=79, @newline="\n", @output=#, @output_width=2> == Usage pp(obj) #=> obj pp obj #=> obj pp(obj1, obj2, ...) #=> [obj1, obj2, ...] pp() #=> nil Output obj(s) to $> in pretty printed format. It returns obj(s). == Output Customization To define a customized pretty printing function for your classes, redefine method #pretty_print(pp) in the class. #pretty_print takes the +pp+ argument, which is an instance of the PP class. The method uses #text, #breakable, #nest, #group and #pp to print the object. == Pretty-Print JSON To pretty-print JSON refer to JSON#pretty_generate. == Author Tanaka Akira
PP.name: PP

PP.pp.description: Outputs +obj+ to +out+ in pretty printed format of +width+ columns in width. If +out+ is omitted, $> is assumed. If +width+ is omitted, 79 is assumed. PP.pp returns +out+.
PP.pp.name: pp

PP.sharing_detection.description:
Returns the sharing detection flag as a boolean value.
It is false by default.
PP.sharing_detection.name: sharing_detection

PP.sharing_detection=.description:
Returns the sharing detection flag as a boolean value.
It is false by default.
PP.sharing_detection=.name: sharing_detection=

PP.singleline_pp.description:
Outputs +obj+ to +out+ like PP.pp but with no indent and
newline.

PP.singleline_pp returns +out+.
PP.singleline_pp.name: singleline_pp

PP::ObjectMixin#pretty_print.description:
A default pretty printing method for general objects.
It calls #pretty_print_instance_variables to list instance variables.

If +self+ has a customized (redefined) #inspect method,
the result of self.inspect is used but it obviously has no
line break hints.

This module provides predefined #pretty_print methods for some of
the most commonly used built-in classes for convenience.
PP::ObjectMixin#pretty_print.name: pretty_print

PP::ObjectMixin#pretty_print_cycle.description:
A default pretty printing method for general objects that are
detected as part of a cycle.
PP::ObjectMixin#pretty_print_cycle.name: pretty_print_cycle

PP::ObjectMixin#pretty_print_inspect.description:
Is #inspect implementation using #pretty_print.
If you implement #pretty_print, it can be used as follows.

  alias inspect pretty_print_inspect

However, doing this requires that every class that #inspect is called on
implement #pretty_print, or a RuntimeError will be raised.
PP::ObjectMixin#pretty_print_inspect.name: pretty_print_inspect

PP::ObjectMixin#pretty_print_instance_va.description:
Returns a sorted array of instance variable names.

This method should return an array of names of instance variables as symbols or strings as:
+[:@a, :@b]+.
PP::ObjectMixin#pretty_print_instance_va.name: pretty_print_instance_variables

PP::PPMethods#check_inspect_key.description:
Check whether the object_id +id+ is in the current buffer of objects
to be pretty printed. Used to break cycles in chains of objects to be
pretty printed.
PP::PPMethods#check_inspect_key.name: check_inspect_key

PP::PPMethods#comma_breakable.description:
A convenience method which is same as follows:

  text ','
  breakable
PP::PPMethods#comma_breakable.name: comma_breakable

PP::PPMethods#guard_inspect_key.description:
Yields to a block
and preserves the previous set of objects being printed.
PP::PPMethods#guard_inspect_key.name: guard_inspect_key

PP::PPMethods#object_address_group.description:
A convenience method, like object_group, but also reformats the Object's
object_id.
PP::PPMethods#object_address_group.name: object_address_group

PP::PPMethods#object_group.description:
A convenience method which is same as follows:

  group(1, '#<' + obj.class.name, '>') { ... }
PP::PPMethods#object_group.name: object_group

PP::PPMethods#pop_inspect_key.description: Removes an object from the set of objects being pretty printed.
PP::PPMethods#pop_inspect_key.name: pop_inspect_key

PP::PPMethods#pp.description:
Adds +obj+ to the pretty printing buffer
using Object#pretty_print or Object#pretty_print_cycle.

Object#pretty_print_cycle is used when +obj+ is already
printed, a.k.a the object reference chain has a cycle.
PP::PPMethods#pp.name: pp

PP::PPMethods#pp_hash.description: A pretty print for a Hash
PP::PPMethods#pp_hash.name: pp_hash

PP::PPMethods#pp_object.description: A present standard failsafe for pretty printing any given Object
PP::PPMethods#pp_object.name: pp_object

PP::PPMethods#push_inspect_key.description:
Adds the object_id +id+ to the set of objects being pretty printed, so
as to not repeat objects.
PP::PPMethods#push_inspect_key.name: push_inspect_key

PP::PPMethods#seplist.description:
Adds a separated list.
The list is separated by comma with breakable space, by default.

#seplist iterates the +list+ using +iter_method+.
It yields each object to the block given for #seplist.
The procedure +separator_proc+ is called between each yields.

If the iteration is zero times, +separator_proc+ is not called at all.

If +separator_proc+ is nil or not given,
+lambda { comma_breakable }+ is used.
If +iter_method+ is not given, :each is used.

For example, following 3 code fragments has similar effect.

  q.seplist([1,2,3]) {|v| xxx v }

  q.seplist([1,2,3], lambda { q.comma_breakable }, :each) {|v| xxx v }

  xxx 1
  q.comma_breakable
  xxx 2
  q.comma_breakable
  xxx 3
PP::PPMethods#seplist.name: seplist

Struct#as_json.description:
Returns a hash, that will be turned into a JSON object and represent this
object.
Struct#as_json.name: as_json

Struct#to_json.description:
Stores class name (Struct) with Struct values <tt>v</tt> as a JSON string.
Only named structs are supported.
Struct#to_json.name: to_json

Struct.json_create.description:
Deserializes JSON string by constructing new Struct object with values
<tt>v</tt> serialized by <tt>to_json</tt>.
Struct.json_create.name: json_create

Range#as_json.description:
Returns a hash, that will be turned into a JSON object and represent this
object.
Range#as_json.name: as_json

Range#to_json.description:
Stores class name (Range) with JSON array of arguments <tt>a</tt> which
include <tt>first</tt> (integer), <tt>last</tt> (integer), and
<tt>exclude_end?</tt> (boolean) as JSON string.
Range#to_json.name: to_json

Range.json_create.description:
Deserializes JSON string by constructing new Range object with arguments
<tt>a</tt> serialized by <tt>to_json</tt>.
Range.json_create.name: json_create

PrettyPrint.description:
This class implements a pretty printing algorithm. It finds line breaks and
nice indentations for grouped structure.

By default, the class assumes that primitive elements are strings and each
byte in the strings have single column in width. But it can be used for
other situations by giving suitable arguments for some methods:
* newline object and space generation block for PrettyPrint.new
* optional width argument for PrettyPrint#text
* PrettyPrint#breakable

There are several candidate uses:
* text formatting using proportional fonts
* multibyte characters which has columns different to number of bytes
* non-string formatting

== Bugs
* Box based formatting?
* Other (better) model/algorithm?

Report any bugs at http://bugs.ruby-lang.org

== References
Christian Lindig, Strictly Pretty, March 2000,
http://www.st.cs.uni-sb.de/~lindig/papers/#pretty

Philip Wadler, A prettier printer, March 1998,
http://homepages.inf.ed.ac.uk/wadler/topics/language-design.html#prettier

== Author
Tanaka Akira <akr@fsij.org>
PrettyPrint.name: PrettyPrint

PrettyPrint#break_outmost_groups.description: Breaks the buffer into lines that are shorter than #maxwidth
PrettyPrint#break_outmost_groups.name: break_outmost_groups

PrettyPrint#breakable.description:
This says "you can break a line here if necessary", and a +width+\-column
text +sep+ is inserted if a line is not broken at the point.

If +sep+ is not specified, " " is used.

If +width+ is not specified, +sep.length+ is used. You will have to
specify this when +sep+ is a multibyte character, for example.
PrettyPrint#breakable.name: breakable

PrettyPrint#current_group.description:
Returns the group most recently added to the stack.

Contrived example:
  out = ""
  => ""
  q = PrettyPrint.new(out)
  => #<PrettyPrint:0x82f85c0 @output="", @maxwidth=79, @newline="\n", @genspace=#<Proc:0x82f8368@/home/vbatts/.rvm/rubies/ruby-head/lib/ruby/2.0.0/prettyprint.rb:82 (lambda)>, @output_width=0, @buffer_width=0, @buffer=[], @group_stack=[#<PrettyPrint::Group:0x82f8138 @depth=0, @breakables=[], @break=false>], @group_queue=#<PrettyPrint::GroupQueue:0x82fb7c0 @queue=[[#<PrettyPrint::Group:0x82f8138 @depth=0, @breakables=[], @break=false>]]>, @indent=0>
  q.group {
    q.text q.current_group.inspect
    q.text q.newline
    q.group(q.current_group.depth + 1) {
      q.text q.current_group.inspect
      q.text q.newline
      q.group(q.current_group.depth + 1) {
        q.text q.current_group.inspect
        q.text q.newline
        q.group(q.current_group.depth + 1) {
          q.text q.current_group.inspect
          q.text q.newline
        }
      }
    }
  }
  => 284
   puts out
  #<PrettyPrint::Group:0x8354758 @depth=1, @breakables=[], @break=false>
  #<PrettyPrint::Group:0x8354550 @depth=2, @breakables=[], @break=false>
  #<PrettyPrint::Group:0x83541cc @depth=3, @breakables=[], @break=false>
  #<PrettyPrint::Group:0x8347e54 @depth=4, @breakables=[], @break=false>
PrettyPrint#current_group.name: current_group

PrettyPrint#fill_breakable.description:
This is similar to #breakable except
the decision to break or not is determined individually.

Two #fill_breakable under a group may cause 4 results:
(break,break), (break,non-break), (non-break,break), (non-break,non-break).
This is different to #breakable because two #breakable under a group
may cause 2 results:
(break,break), (non-break,non-break).

The text +sep+ is inserted if a line is not broken at this point.

If +sep+ is not specified, " " is used.

If +width+ is not specified, +sep.length+ is used. You will have to
specify this when +sep+ is a multibyte character, for example.
PrettyPrint#fill_breakable.name: fill_breakable

PrettyPrint#genspace.description:
A lambda or Proc, that takes one argument, of a Fixnum, and returns
the corresponding number of spaces.

By default this is:
  lambda {|n| ' ' * n}
PrettyPrint#genspace.name: genspace

PrettyPrint#group.description:
Groups line break hints added in the block. The line break hints are all
to be used or not.

If +indent+ is specified, the method call is regarded as nested by
nest(indent) { ... }.

If +open_obj+ is specified, <tt>text open_obj, open_width</tt> is called
before grouping. If +close_obj+ is specified, <tt>text close_obj,
close_width</tt> is called after grouping.
PrettyPrint#group.name: group

PrettyPrint#group_queue.description: The PrettyPrint::GroupQueue of groups in stack to be pretty printed
PrettyPrint#group_queue.name: group_queue

PrettyPrint#group_sub.description: Takes a block and queues a new group that is indented 1 level further.
PrettyPrint#group_sub.name: group_sub

PrettyPrint#indent.description: The number of spaces to be indented
PrettyPrint#indent.name: indent

PrettyPrint#initialize.description:
Creates a buffer for pretty printing.

+output+ is an output target. If it is not specified, '' is assumed. It
should have a << method which accepts the first argument +obj+ of
PrettyPrint#text, the first argument +sep+ of PrettyPrint#breakable, the
first argument +newline+ of PrettyPrint.new, and the result of a given
block for PrettyPrint.new.

+maxwidth+ specifies maximum line length. If it is not specified, 79 is
assumed. However actual outputs may overflow +maxwidth+ if long
non-breakable texts are provided.

+newline+ is used for line breaks. "\n" is used if it is not specified.

The block is used to generate spaces. {|width| ' ' * width} is used if it
is not given.
PrettyPrint#initialize.name: initialize

PrettyPrint#maxwidth.description:
The maximum width of a line, before it is separated in to a newline

This defaults to 79, and should be a Fixnum
PrettyPrint#maxwidth.name: maxwidth

PrettyPrint#nest.description:
Increases left margin after newline with +indent+ for line breaks added in
the block.
PrettyPrint#nest.name: nest

PrettyPrint#newline.description:
The value that is appended to +output+ to add a new line.

This defaults to "\n", and should be String
PrettyPrint#newline.name: newline

PrettyPrint#output.description:
The output object.

This defaults to '', and should accept the << method
PrettyPrint#output.name: output

PrettyPrint#text.description:
This adds +obj+ as a text of +width+ columns in width.

If +width+ is not specified, obj.length is used.
PrettyPrint#text.name: text

PrettyPrint.format.description:
This is a convenience method which is same as follows:

  begin
    q = PrettyPrint.new(output, maxwidth, newline, &genspace)
    ...
    q.flush
    output
  end
PrettyPrint.format.name: format

PrettyPrint.singleline_format.description:
This is similar to PrettyPrint::format but the result has no breaks.

+maxwidth+, +newline+ and +genspace+ are ignored.

The invocation of +breakable+ in the block doesn't break a line and is
treated as just an invocation of +text+.
PrettyPrint.singleline_format.name: singleline_format

PrettyPrint::Breakable.description:
The Breakable class is used for breaking up object information

This class is intended for internal use of the PrettyPrint buffers.
PrettyPrint::Breakable.name: Breakable

PrettyPrint::Breakable#indent.description:
The number of spaces to indent.

This is inferred from +q+ within PrettyPrint, passed in ::new
PrettyPrint::Breakable#indent.name: indent

PrettyPrint::Breakable#initialize.description:
Create a new Breakable object.

Arguments:
* +sep+ String of the separator
* +width+ Fixnum width of the +sep+
* +q+ parent PrettyPrint object, to base from
PrettyPrint::Breakable#initialize.name: initialize

PrettyPrint::Breakable#obj.description:
Holds the separator String

The +sep+ argument from ::new
PrettyPrint::Breakable#obj.name: obj

PrettyPrint::Breakable#output.description:
Render the String text of the objects that have been added to this
Breakable object.

Output the text to +out+, and increment the width to +output_width+
PrettyPrint::Breakable#output.name: output

PrettyPrint::Group.description:
The Group class is used for making indentation easier.

While this class does neither the breaking into newlines nor indentation,
it is used in a stack (as well as a queue) within PrettyPrint, to group
objects.

For information on using groups, see PrettyPrint#group

This class is intended for internal use of the PrettyPrint buffers.
PrettyPrint::Group.name: Group

PrettyPrint::Group#break.description: Makes a break for this Group, and returns true
PrettyPrint::Group#break.name: break

PrettyPrint::Group#break?.description: Boolean of whether this Group has made a break
PrettyPrint::Group#break?.name: break?

PrettyPrint::Group#breakables.description: Array to hold the Breakable objects for this Group
PrettyPrint::Group#breakables.name: breakables

PrettyPrint::Group#depth.description: This group's relation to previous groups
PrettyPrint::Group#depth.name: depth

PrettyPrint::Group#first?.description:
Boolean of whether this Group has been queried for being first

This is used as a predicate, and ought to be called first.
PrettyPrint::Group#first?.name: first?

PrettyPrint::Group#initialize.description:
Create a Group object

Arguments:
* +depth+ - this group's relation to previous groups
PrettyPrint::Group#initialize.name: initialize

PrettyPrint::GroupQueue.description:
The GroupQueue class is used for managing the queue of Group to be pretty
printed.

This queue groups the Group objects, based on their depth.

This class is intended for internal use of the PrettyPrint buffers.
PrettyPrint::GroupQueue.name: GroupQueue

PrettyPrint::GroupQueue#deq.description: Returns the outer group of the queue
PrettyPrint::GroupQueue#deq.name: deq

PrettyPrint::GroupQueue#enq.description:
Enqueue +group+

This does not strictly append the group to the end of the queue,
but instead adds it in line, base on the +group.depth+
PrettyPrint::GroupQueue#enq.name: enq

PrettyPrint::GroupQueue#initialize.description:
Create a GroupQueue object

Arguments:
* +groups+ - one or more PrettyPrint::Group objects
PrettyPrint::GroupQueue#initialize.name: initialize

PrettyPrint::SingleLine.description:
PrettyPrint::SingleLine is used by PrettyPrint.singleline_format

It is passed to be similar to a PrettyPrint object itself, by responding to:
* #text
* #breakable
* #nest
* #group
* #flush
* #first?

but instead, the output has no line breaks
PrettyPrint::SingleLine.name: SingleLine

PrettyPrint::SingleLine#breakable.description:
Appends +sep+ to the text to be output. By default +sep+ is ' '

+width+ argument is here for compatibility. It is a noop argument.
PrettyPrint::SingleLine#breakable.name: breakable

PrettyPrint::SingleLine#first?.description: This is used as a predicate, and ought to be called first.
PrettyPrint::SingleLine#first?.name: first?

PrettyPrint::SingleLine#flush.description: Method present for compatibility, but is a noop
PrettyPrint::SingleLine#flush.name: flush

PrettyPrint::SingleLine#group.description:
Opens a block for grouping objects to be pretty printed.

Arguments:
* +indent+ - noop argument. Present for compatibility.
* +open_obj+ - text appended before the &blok. Default is ''
* +close_obj+ - text appended after the &blok. Default is ''
* +open_width+ - noop argument. Present for compatibility.
* +close_width+ - noop argument. Present for compatibility.
PrettyPrint::SingleLine#group.name: group

PrettyPrint::SingleLine#initialize.description:
Create a PrettyPrint::SingleLine object

Arguments:
* +output+ - String (or similar) to store rendered text. Needs to respond to '<<'
* +maxwidth+ - Argument position expected to be here for compatibility.
               This argument is a noop.
* +newline+ - Argument position expected to be here for compatibility.
              This argument is a noop.
PrettyPrint::SingleLine#initialize.name: initialize

PrettyPrint::SingleLine#nest.description:
Takes +indent+ arg, but does nothing with it.

Yields to a block.
PrettyPrint::SingleLine#nest.name: nest

PrettyPrint::SingleLine#text.description:
Add +obj+ to the text to be output.

+width+ argument is here for compatibility. It is a noop argument.
PrettyPrint::SingleLine#text.name: text

PrettyPrint::Text.description:
The Text class is the means by which to collect strings from objects.

This class is intended for internal use of the PrettyPrint buffers.
PrettyPrint::Text.name: Text

PrettyPrint::Text#add.description:
Include +obj+ in the objects to be pretty printed, and increment
this Text object's total width by +width+
PrettyPrint::Text#add.name: add

PrettyPrint::Text#initialize.description:
Creates a new text object.

This constructor takes no arguments.

The workflow is to append a PrettyPrint::Text object to the buffer, and
being able to call the buffer.last() to reference it.

As there are objects, use PrettyPrint::Text#add to include the objects
and the width to utilized by the String version of this object.
PrettyPrint::Text#initialize.name: initialize

PrettyPrint::Text#output.description:
Render the String text of the objects that have been added to this Text object.

Output the text to +out+, and increment the width to +output_width+
PrettyPrint::Text#output.name: output

PrettyPrint::Text#width.description: The total width of the objects included in this Text object.
PrettyPrint::Text#width.name: width

Gem.description:
--
This file contains all sorts of little compatibility hacks that we've
had to introduce over the years. Quarantining them into one file helps
us know when we can get rid of them.

Ruby 1.9.x has introduced some things that are awkward, and we need to
support them, so we define some constants to use later.
++
Gem.name: Gem

Gem.bin_path.description:
Find the full path to the executable for gem +name+.  If the +exec_name+
is not given, the gem's default_executable is chosen, otherwise the
specified executable's path is returned.  +requirements+ allows
you to specify specific gem versions.
Gem.bin_path.name: bin_path

Gem.binary_mode.description: The mode needed to read a file as straight binary.
Gem.binary_mode.name: binary_mode

Gem.bindir.description: The path where gem executables are to be installed.
Gem.bindir.name: bindir

Gem.clear_default_specs.description: Clear default gem related variables. It is for test
Gem.clear_default_specs.name: clear_default_specs

Gem.clear_paths.description:
Reset the +dir+ and +path+ values.  The next time +dir+ or +path+
is requested, the values will be calculated from scratch.  This is
mainly used by the unit tests to provide test isolation.
Gem.clear_paths.name: clear_paths

Gem.config_file.description: The path to standard location of the user's .gemrc file.

Whether to expect full paths in default gems - true for non-MRI

Gem.default_sources.name: default_sources

Default spec directory path to be used if an alternate value is not

Gem.default_spec_cache_dir.name: default_spec_cache_dir

Gem.detect_gemdeps.description: Looks for a gem dependency file at +path+ and activates the gems in the file if found. If the file is not found an ArgumentError is raised. If +path+ is not given the RUBYGEMS_GEMDEPS environment variable is used, but if no file is found no exception is raised. If '-' is given for +path+ RubyGems searches up from the current working directory for gem dependency files (gem.deps.rb, Gemfile, Isolate) and activates the gems in the first one found. You can run this automatically when rubygems starts. To enable, set the RUBYGEMS_GEMDEPS environment variable to either the path of your gem dependencies file or "-" to auto-discover in parent directories. NOTE: Enabling automatic discovery on multiuser systems can lead to execution of arbitrary code when used from directories outside your control.
Gem.detect_gemdeps.name: detect_gemdeps

Gem.dir.description:
The path where gems are to be installed.
--
FIXME deprecate these once everything else has been done -ebh
Gem.dir.name: dir

Gem.done_installing.description:
Adds a post-installs hook that will be passed a Gem::DependencyInstaller
and a list of installed specifications when
Gem::DependencyInstaller#install is complete
Gem.done_installing.name: done_installing

Gem.done_installing_hooks.description:
The list of hooks to be run after Gem::DependencyInstaller installs a
set of gems
Gem.done_installing_hooks.name: done_installing_hooks

Gem.ensure_default_gem_subdirectories.description:
Quietly ensure the Gem directory +dir+ contains all the proper
subdirectories for handling default gems.  If we can't create a
directory due to a permission problem, then we will silently continue.

If +mode+ is given, missing directories are created with this mode.

World-writable directories will never be created.
Gem.ensure_default_gem_subdirectories.name: ensure_default_gem_subdirectories

Gem.ensure_gem_subdirectories.description:
Quietly ensure the Gem directory +dir+ contains all the proper
subdirectories.  If we can't create a directory due to a permission
problem, then we will silently continue.

If +mode+ is given, missing directories are created with this mode.

World-writable directories will never be created.
Gem.ensure_gem_subdirectories.name: ensure_gem_subdirectories

Gem.extension_api_version.description:
The extension API version of ruby.  This includes the static vs non-static
distinction as extensions cannot be shared between the two.
Gem.extension_api_version.name: extension_api_version

Gem.find_files.description:
Returns a list of paths matching +glob+ that can be used by a gem to pick
up features from other gems.  For example:

  Gem.find_files('rdoc/discover').each do |path| load path end

if +check_load_path+ is true (the default), then find_files also searches
$LOAD_PATH for files as well as gems.

Note that find_files will return all files even if they are from different
versions of the same gem.  See also find_latest_files
Gem.find_files.name: find_files

Gem.find_home.description:
Finds the user's home directory.
--
Some comments from the ruby-talk list regarding finding the home
directory:

  I have HOME, USERPROFILE and HOMEDRIVE + HOMEPATH. Ruby seems
  to be depending on HOME in those code samples. I propose that
  it should fallback to USERPROFILE and HOMEDRIVE + HOMEPATH (at
  least on Win32).
++
--

FIXME move to pathsupport

++
Gem.find_home.name: find_home

Gem.find_latest_files.description:
Returns a list of paths matching +glob+ from the latest gems that can be
used by a gem to pick up features from other gems.  For example:

  Gem.find_latest_files('rdoc/discover').each do |path| load path end

if +check_load_path+ is true (the default), then find_latest_files also
searches $LOAD_PATH for files as well as gems.

Unlike find_files, find_latest_files will return only files from the
latest version of a gem.
Gem.find_latest_files.name: find_latest_files

Gem.find_unresolved_default_spec.description: Find a Gem::Specification of default gem from +path+
Gem.find_unresolved_default_spec.name: find_unresolved_default_spec

Gem.host.description:
Get the default RubyGems API host. This is normally
<tt>https://rubygems.org</tt>.

Gem.host=.description: Set the default RubyGems API host.
Gem.host=.name: host=

Gem.install.description:
Top level install helper method. Allows you to install gems interactively:

  % irb
  >> Gem.install "minitest"
  Fetching: minitest-3.0.1.gem (100%)
  => [#<Gem::Specification:0x1013b4528 @name="minitest", ...>]

Gem.location_of_caller.description: The file name and line number of the caller of the caller of this method.
Gem.location_of_caller.name: location_of_caller

Gem.marshal_version.description: The version of the Marshal format for your Ruby.
Gem.marshal_version.name: marshal_version

Gem.path_separator.description: How String Gem paths should be split.  Overridable for esoteric platforms.

Initialize the filesystem paths to use from +env+.
+env+ is a hash-like object (typically ENV) that

Gem.platforms=.name: platforms=

Gem.post_build.description:
Adds a post-build hook that will be passed an Gem::Installer instance
when Gem::Installer#install is called.  The hook is called after the gem
has been extracted and extensions have been built but before the
executables or gemspec has been written.  If the hook returns +false+ then
the gem's files will be removed and the install will be aborted.
Gem.post_build.name: post_build

Gem.post_build_hooks.description:
The list of hooks to be run after Gem::Installer#install extracts files
and builds extensions
Gem.post_build_hooks.name: post_build_hooks

Gem.post_install.description:
Adds a post-install hook that will be passed an Gem::Installer instance
when Gem::Installer#install is called
Gem.post_install.name: post_install

Gem.post_install_hooks.description:
The list of hooks to be run after Gem::Installer#install completes
installation
Gem.post_install_hooks.name: post_install_hooks

Gem.post_reset.description:
Adds a hook that will get run after Gem::Specification.reset is
run.
Gem.post_reset.name: post_reset

Gem.post_reset_hooks.description: The list of hooks to be run after Gem::Specification.reset is run.
Gem.post_reset_hooks.name: post_reset_hooks

Adds a post-uninstall hook that will be passed a Gem::Uninstaller instance

Gem.post_uninstall.name: post_uninstall

Gem.post_uninstall_hooks.description:
The list of hooks to be run after Gem::Uninstaller#uninstall completes

Gem.post_uninstall_hooks.name: post_uninstall_hooks

Gem.pre_install.description:
Adds a pre-install hook that will be passed an Gem::Installer instance
when Gem::Installer#install is called.  If the hook returns +false+ then
the install will be aborted.
Gem.pre_install.name: pre_install

Gem.pre_install_hooks.description: The list of hooks to be run before Gem::Installer#install does any work
Gem.pre_install_hooks.name: pre_install_hooks

Gem.pre_reset.description:
Adds a hook that will get run before Gem::Specification.reset is
run.
Gem.pre_reset.name: pre_reset

Gem.pre_reset_hooks.description: The list of hooks to be run before Gem::Specification.reset is run.
Gem.pre_reset_hooks.name: pre_reset_hooks

Gem.pre_uninstall.description:
Adds a pre-uninstall hook that will be passed an Gem::Uninstaller instance
and the spec that will be uninstalled when Gem::Uninstaller#uninstall is

Gem.pre_uninstall_hooks.description:
The list of hooks to be run before Gem::Uninstaller#uninstall does any

Gem.pre_uninstall_hooks.name: pre_uninstall_hooks

Gem.prefix.description:
The directory prefix this RubyGems was installed at. If your
prefix is in a standard location (ie, rubygems is installed where

Gem.read_binary.description: Safely read a file in binary mode on all platforms.
Gem.read_binary.name: read_binary

Gem.register_default_spec.description:
Register a Gem::Specification for default gem.

Two formats for the specification are supported:

* MRI 2.0 style, where spec.files contains unprefixed require names.
  The spec's filenames will be registered as-is.
* New style, where spec.files contains files prefixed with paths
  from spec.require_paths. The prefixes are stripped before
  registering the spec's filenames. Unprefixed files are omitted.
Gem.register_default_spec.name: register_default_spec

Gem.remove_unresolved_default_spec.description:
Remove needless Gem::Specification of default gem from
unresolved default gem list
Gem.remove_unresolved_default_spec.name: remove_unresolved_default_spec

Gem.ui.description: Lazily loads DefaultUserInteraction and returns the default UI.
Gem.ui.name: ui

Gem.use_gemdeps.description: Looks for a gem dependency file at +path+ and activates the gems in the file if found. If the file is not found an ArgumentError is raised. If +path+ is not given the RUBYGEMS_GEMDEPS environment variable is used, but if no file is found no exception is raised. If '-' is given for +path+ RubyGems searches up from the current working directory for gem dependency files (gem.deps.rb, Gemfile, Isolate) and activates the gems in the first one found. You can run this automatically when rubygems starts. To enable, set the RUBYGEMS_GEMDEPS environment variable to either the path of your gem dependencies file or "-" to auto-discover in parent directories. NOTE: Enabling automatic discovery on multiuser systems can lead to execution of arbitrary code when used from directories outside your control.

Gem.use_paths.description:
Use the +home+ and +paths+ values for Gem.dir and Gem.path.  Used mainly

Gem.user_dir.description: Path for gems in the user's home directory

Gem.vendor_dir.description: Directory where vendor gems are installed.

Gem::BasicSpecification.description:
BasicSpecification is an abstract class which implements some common code
used by both Specification and StubSpecification.
Gem::BasicSpecification.name: BasicSpecification

Gem::BasicSpecification#activated?.description: True when the gem has been activated
Gem::BasicSpecification#activated?.name: activated?

Gem::BasicSpecification#base_dir.description:
Returns the full path to the base gem directory.

eg: /usr/local/lib/ruby/gems/1.8
Gem::BasicSpecification#base_dir.name: base_dir

Gem::BasicSpecification#base_dir=.description: Allows installation of extensions for git: gems.
Gem::BasicSpecification#base_dir=.name: base_dir=

Gem::BasicSpecification#contains_requira.description: Return true if this spec can require +file+.
Gem::BasicSpecification#contains_requira.name: contains_requirable_file?

Gem::BasicSpecification#extension_dir.description: Returns full path to the directory where gem's extensions are installed.
Gem::BasicSpecification#extension_dir.name: extension_dir

Gem::BasicSpecification#extension_dir=.description: Sets the directory where extensions for this gem will be installed.
Gem::BasicSpecification#extension_dir=.name: extension_dir=

Gem::BasicSpecification#extensions_dir.description: Returns path to the extensions directory.
Gem::BasicSpecification#extensions_dir.name: extensions_dir

Gem::BasicSpecification#full_gem_path.description: The full path to the gem (install path + full name).
Gem::BasicSpecification#full_gem_path.name: full_gem_path

Gem::BasicSpecification#full_gem_path=.description: Allows correct activation of git: and path: gems.
Gem::BasicSpecification#full_gem_path=.name: full_gem_path=

Gem::BasicSpecification#full_name.description:
Returns the full name (name-version) of this Gem.  Platform information
is included (name-version-platform) if it is specified and not the
default Ruby platform.
Gem::BasicSpecification#full_name.name: full_name

Gem::BasicSpecification#full_require_pat.description: Full paths in the gem to add to $LOAD_PATH when this gem is activated.
Gem::BasicSpecification#full_require_pat.name: full_require_paths

Gem::BasicSpecification#gem_dir.description:
Returns the full path to this spec's gem directory.
eg: /usr/local/lib/ruby/1.8/gems/mygem-1.0
Gem::BasicSpecification#gem_dir.name: gem_dir

Gem::BasicSpecification#gems_dir.description:
Returns the full path to the gems directory containing this spec's

Gem::BasicSpecification#ignored=.name: ignored=

Gem::BasicSpecification#loaded_from.description: The path this gemspec was loaded from.  This attribute is not persisted.
Gem::BasicSpecification#loaded_from.name: loaded_from

Set the path the Specification was loaded from. +path+ is converted to a

Gem::BasicSpecification#require_paths.description: Paths in the gem to add to $LOAD_PATH when this gem is activated. See also #require_paths= If you have an extension you do not need to add "ext" to the require path, the extension build process will copy the extension files into "lib" for you. The default value is "lib" Usage: # If all library files are in the root directory... spec.require_path = '.'
Gem::BasicSpecification#require_paths.name: require_paths

Gem::BasicSpecification#source_paths.description:
Returns the paths to the source files for use with analysis and
documentation tools.  These paths are relative to full_gem_path.
Gem::BasicSpecification#source_paths.name: source_paths

Gem::BasicSpecification#to_spec.description: Return a Gem::Specification from this gem
Gem::BasicSpecification#to_spec.name: to_spec

Gem::Command.description:
Base class for all Gem commands.  When creating a new gem command, define
#initialize, #execute, #arguments, #defaults_str, #description and #usage
(as appropriate).  See the above mentioned methods for details.

A very good example to look at is Gem::Commands::ContentsCommand
Gem::Command.name: Command

Gem::Command#add_option.description:
Add a command-line option and handler to the command.

See OptionParser#make_switch for an explanation of +opts+.

+handler+ will be called with two values, the value of the argument and
the options hash.

If the first argument of add_option is a Symbol, it's used to group
options in output.  See `gem help list` for an example.
Gem::Command#add_option.name: add_option

Gem::Command#add_parser_run_info.description:
Adds a section with +title+ and +content+ to the parser help view.  Used
for adding command arguments and default arguments.
Gem::Command#add_parser_run_info.name: add_parser_run_info

Gem::Command#arguments.description:
Override to provide details of the arguments a command takes.  It should
return a left-justified string, one argument per line.

For example:

  def usage
    "#{program_name} FILE [FILE ...]"
  end

  def arguments
    "FILE          name of file to find"
  end
Gem::Command#arguments.name: arguments

Gem::Command#begins?.description: True if +long+ begins with the characters from +short+.
Gem::Command#begins?.name: begins?

Gem::Command#create_option_parser.description:
Creates an option parser and fills it in with the help info for the
command.
Gem::Command#create_option_parser.name: create_option_parser

Gem::Command#defaults.description: The default options for the command.
Gem::Command#defaults.name: defaults

Gem::Command#defaults=.description: The default options for the command.
Gem::Command#defaults=.name: defaults=

Gem::Command#defaults_str.description:
Override to display the default values of the command options. (similar to
+arguments+, but displays the default values).

For example:

  def defaults_str
    --no-gems-first --no-all
  end
Gem::Command#defaults_str.name: defaults_str

Gem::Command#description.description: Override to display a longer description of what this command does.
Gem::Command#description.name: description

Gem::Command#execute.description:
Override to provide command handling.

#options will be filled in with your parsed options, unparsed options will
be left in <tt>options[:args]</tt>.

See also: #get_all_gem_names, #get_one_gem_name,
#get_one_optional_argument
Gem::Command#execute.name: execute

Gem::Command#get_all_gem_names.description: Get all gem names from the command line.
Gem::Command#get_all_gem_names.name: get_all_gem_names

Gem::Command#get_all_gem_names_and_versi.description:
Get all [gem, version] from the command line.

An argument in the form gem:ver is pull apart into the gen name and version,
respectively.
Gem::Command#get_all_gem_names_and_versi.name: get_all_gem_names_and_versions

Gem::Command#get_one_gem_name.description:
Get a single gem name from the command line.  Fail if there is no gem name
or if there is more than one gem name given.
Gem::Command#get_one_gem_name.name: get_one_gem_name

Gem::Command#get_one_optional_argument.description:
Get a single optional argument from the command line.  If more than one
argument is given, return only the first. Return nil if none are given.
Gem::Command#get_one_optional_argument.name: get_one_optional_argument

Gem::Command#handle_options.description:
Handle the given list of arguments by parsing them and recording the
results.
Gem::Command#handle_options.name: handle_options

Gem::Command#handles?.description: True if the command handles the given argument list.
Gem::Command#handles?.name: handles?

Gem::Command#initialize.description:
Initializes a generic gem command named +command+.  +summary+ is a short
description displayed in `gem help commands`.  +defaults+ are the default
options.  Defaults should be mirrored in #defaults_str, unless there are
none.

When defining a new command subclass, use add_option to add command-line
switches.

Unhandled arguments (gem names, files, etc.) are left in
<tt>options[:args]</tt>.
Gem::Command#initialize.name: initialize

Gem::Command#invoke.description: Invoke the command with the given list of arguments.
Gem::Command#invoke.name: invoke

Gem::Command#invoke_with_build_args.description:
Invoke the command with the given list of normal arguments
and additional build arguments.
Gem::Command#invoke_with_build_args.name: invoke_with_build_args

Gem::Command#merge_options.description:
Merge a set of command options with the set of default options (without
modifying the default option hash).
Gem::Command#merge_options.name: merge_options

Gem::Command#program_name.description: The name of the command for command-line invocation.
Gem::Command#program_name.name: program_name

Gem::Command#program_name=.description: The name of the command for command-line invocation.
Gem::Command#program_name=.name: program_name=

Gem::Command#show_help.description: Display the help message for the command.
Gem::Command#show_help.name: show_help

Gem::Command#show_lookup_failure.description:
Display to the user that a gem couldn't be found and reasons why
--
TODO: replace +domain+ with a parameter to suppress suggestions
Gem::Command#show_lookup_failure.name: show_lookup_failure

Gem::CommandManager.description:
The command manager registers and installs all the individual sub-commands
supported by the gem command.

Extra commands can be provided by writing a rubygems_plugin.rb
file in an installed gem.  You should register your command against the
Gem::CommandManager instance, like this:

  # file rubygems_plugin.rb
  require 'rubygems/command_manager'

  Gem::CommandManager.instance.register_command :edit

You should put the implementation of your command in rubygems/commands.

  # file rubygems/commands/edit_command.rb
  class Gem::Commands::EditCommand < Gem::Command
    # ...
  end

See Gem::Command for instructions on writing gem commands.
Gem::CommandManager.name: CommandManager

Gem::ConfigFile.description:
Gem::ConfigFile RubyGems options and gem command options from gemrc.

gemrc is a YAML file that uses strings to match gem command arguments and
symbols to match RubyGems options.

Gem command arguments use a String key that matches the command name and
allow you to specify default arguments:

  install: --no-rdoc --no-ri
  update: --no-rdoc --no-ri

You can use <tt>gem:</tt> to set default arguments for all commands.

RubyGems options use symbol keys.  Valid options are:

+:backtrace+:: See #backtrace
+:sources+:: Sets Gem::sources
+:verbose+:: See #verbose

gemrc files may exist in various locations and are read and merged in
the following order:

- system wide (/etc/gemrc)
- per user (~/.gemrc)
- per environment (gemrc files listed in the GEMRC environment variable)
Gem::ConfigFile.name: ConfigFile

Gem::ConfigFile#backtrace.name: backtrace

Gem::ConfigFile#backtrace=.name: backtrace=

Gem::ConfigFile#initialize.description:
Create the config file object.  +args+ is the list of arguments
from the command line.

The following command line options are handled early here rather
than later at the time most command options are processed.

<tt>--config-file</tt>, <tt>--config-file==NAME</tt>::
  Obviously these need to be handled by the ConfigFile object to ensure we
  get the right config file.

<tt>--backtrace</tt>::
  Backtrace needs to be turned on early so that errors before normal
  option parsing can be properly handled.

<tt>--debug</tt>::
  Enable Ruby level debug messages.  Handled early for the same reason as
  --backtrace.
--
TODO: parse options upstream, pass in options directly

Gem::Dependency#===.description:
Uses this dependency as a pattern to compare to +other+. This
dependency will match if the name matches the other's name, and
other has only an equal version requirement that satisfies this

Gem::Dependency#=~.description:
Uses this dependency as a pattern to compare to +other+. This
dependency will match if the name matches the other's name, and
other has only an equal version requirement that satisfies this
dependency.

Gem::Dependency#match?.description:
:call-seq:

  dep.match? name, version => true or false
  dep.match? spec          => true or false

Does this dependency match the specification described by +name+ and
+version+ or match +spec+?

NOTE:  Unlike #matches_spec? this method does not return true when the
version is a prerelease version unless this is a prerelease dependency.
Gem::Dependency#match?.name: match?

Gem::Dependency#matches_spec?.description:
Does this dependency match +spec+?

NOTE:  This is not a convenience method.  Unlike #match? this method
returns true when +spec+ is a prerelease version even if this dependency

Gem::DependencyInstaller#initialize.description:
Creates a new installer instance.

Options are:
:cache_dir:: Alternate repository path to store .gem files in.
:domain:: :local, :remote, or :both.  :local only searches gems in the
          current directory.  :remote searches only gems in Gem::sources.
          :both searches both.
:env_shebang:: See Gem::Installer::new.
:force:: See Gem::Installer#install.
:format_executable:: See Gem::Installer#initialize.
:ignore_dependencies:: Don't install any dependencies.
:install_dir:: See Gem::Installer#install.
:prerelease:: Allow prerelease versions.  See #install.
:security_policy:: See Gem::Installer::new and Gem::Security.
:user_install:: See Gem::Installer.new
:wrappers:: See Gem::Installer::new
:build_args:: See Gem::Installer::new
Gem::DependencyInstaller#initialize.name: initialize

Gem::DependencyInstaller#install.description:
Installs the gem +dep_or_name+ and all its dependencies.  Returns an Array
of installed gem specifications.

If the +:prerelease+ option is set and there is a prerelease for
+dep_or_name+ the prerelease version will be installed.

Unless explicitly specified as a prerelease dependency, prerelease gems
that +dep_or_name+ depend on will not be installed.

If c-1.a depends on b-1 and a-1.a and there is a gem b-1.a available then
c-1.a, b-1 and a-1.a will be installed.  b-1.a will need to be installed
separately.
Gem::DependencyInstaller#install.name: install

Gem::DependencyInstaller#installed_gems.description: List of gems installed by #install in alphabetic order
Gem::DependencyInstaller#installed_gems.name: installed_gems

Gem::DependencyList.description:
Gem::DependencyList is used for installing and uninstalling gems in the
correct order to avoid conflicts.
--
TODO: It appears that all but topo-sort functionality is being duplicated
(or is planned to be duplicated) elsewhere in rubygems.  Is the majority of
this class necessary anymore?  Especially #ok?, #why_not_ok?
Gem::DependencyList.name: DependencyList

Gem::DependencyList#active_count.description:
Count the number of gemspecs in the list +specs+ that are not in
+ignored+.
Gem::DependencyList#active_count.name: active_count

Gem::DependencyList#dependency_order.description:
Return a list of the gem specifications in the dependency list, sorted in
order so that no gemspec in the list depends on a gemspec earlier in the
list.

This is useful when removing gems from a set of installed gems.  By
removing them in the returned order, you don't get into as many dependency
issues.

If there are circular dependencies (yuck!), then gems will be returned in
order until only the circular dependents and anything they reference are
left.  Then arbitrary gemspecs will be returned until the circular
dependency is broken, after which gems will be returned in dependency
order again.
Gem::DependencyList#dependency_order.name: dependency_order

Gem::Deprecate.description:
Provides a single method +deprecate+ to be used to declare when
something is going away.

    class Legacy
      def self.klass_method
        # ...
      end

      def instance_method
        # ...
      end

      extend Gem::Deprecate
      deprecate :instance_method, "X.z", 2011, 4

      class << self
        extend Gem::Deprecate
        deprecate :klass_method, :none, 2011, 4
      end
    end
Gem::Deprecate.name: Deprecate

Gem::Deprecate#deprecate.description:
Simple deprecation method that deprecates +name+ by wrapping it up
in a dummy method. It warns on each call to the dummy method
telling the user of +repl+ (unless +repl+ is :none) and the
year/month that it is planned to go away.
Gem::Deprecate#deprecate.name: deprecate

Gem::Deprecate#skip_during.description: Temporarily turn off warnings. Intended for tests only.
Gem::Deprecate#skip_during.name: skip_during

Gem::FakeFetcher.description:
A fake Gem::RemoteFetcher for use in tests or to avoid real live HTTP
requests when testing code that uses RubyGems.

Example:

  @fetcher = Gem::FakeFetcher.new
  @fetcher.data['http://gems.example.com/yaml'] = source_index.to_yaml
  Gem::RemoteFetcher.fetcher = @fetcher

  # invoke RubyGems code

  paths = @fetcher.paths
  assert_equal 'http://gems.example.com/yaml', paths.shift
  assert paths.empty?, paths.join(', ')

See RubyGems' tests for more examples of FakeFetcher.
Gem::FakeFetcher.name: FakeFetcher

Gem::Installer.description:
The installer installs the files contained in the .gem into the Gem.home.

Gem::Installer does the work of putting files in all the right places on the
filesystem including unpacking the gem into its gem dir, installing the
gemspec in the specifications dir, storing the cached gem in the cache dir,
and installing either wrappers or symlinks for executables.

The installer invokes pre and post install hooks.  Hooks can be added either
through a rubygems_plugin.rb file in an installed gem or via a
rubygems/defaults/#{RUBY_ENGINE}.rb or rubygems/defaults/operating_system.rb
file.  See Gem.pre_install and Gem.post_install for details.
Gem::Installer.name: Installer
